g.text: cant weakening of the polar vortex
December 2016 and the passing of an Madden
Stratospheric polar vortex variations and their downward
coupling to the surface are a key driver of variations of the SAM
upward propagation of planetary wave activity from the upper
troposphere into the stratosphere weakened the polar vortex in
propagated downward to the surface (Fig. 4a), promoting low
SAM and weakened circumpolar surface westerlies during
Dec (Fig. 4b). This weakening of the polar vortex is viewed
as an earlier than normal breakdown of the vortex that typically
occurs in late spring (compare the anomalous zonal winds to the
climatological zonal winds in Fig. 4a). This coupling of the
weakened surface circumpolar westerlies during Nov
preceding weakening of the stratospheric polar vortex during
Figure 4a) and is also supported in reforecasts with a coupled
tion of the polar stratospheric ozone with a substantially smaller
The enhanced polar stratospheric ozone in these months can also
be associated with low SAM in subsequent months
strong coupling between the polar vortex and ozone anomalies.
During early November 2016, a strong MJO traversed the IO
that acted to suppress convection in the eastern IO and enhance
This MJO event thus acted to rapidly weaken the SST anomalies
(Supplementary Figure 6b) associated with the negative IOD
which were the source of the wave-3 pattern during Sep
2016. Thus the MJO helped to enable the more zonally uniform
weakening of the circumpolar surface westerlies, in response to
the earlier than normal breakdown of the polar stratospheric
Though the circulation anomalies associated with SAM are
predominantly annular, its impact on sea-ice is non-annular

wave source (RWS, magenta contours, positive (anticyclonic) solid and negative (cyclonic) dashed, zero line omitted; interval 4 × 10
and outgoing longwave radiation (OLR) anomaly (shading; interval 4 Wm
linear regression onto the DMI index (
) using historical data for the period 1979
are scaled by the observed magnitude of the DMI and Nino34 index, respectively, in Sep
-test. For clarity, divergent wind weaker than 0.8 ms
are masked. In the Southern Hemisphere, negative streamfunction anomaly corresponds to positive geopotential height anomaly and
thus is coloured in reds; similarly, positive streamfunction anomaly is coloured in blues. Plots were generated using the NCAR Command Language version
